topics.learning_outcome: Differentiate between living and non-living things in the environment
key_concepts: Living things grow, reproduce, and respond to stimuli
Non-living things do not need food, water, or air

topics.learning_outcome: Identify the basic needs of living things (air, water, food, shelter)
key_concepts: All living things need air, water, food, and shelter to survive
Without these, they cannot live for long

topics.learning_outcome: Identify plant and animal parts and their roles in survival
key_concepts: Roots absorb water, leaves make food, stems transport nutrients
Animal body parts help them move, eat, and protect themselves

topics.learning_outcome: Describe how plants and animals change as they grow
key_concepts: Identify body part changes in animals as they grow
Plants (mongo seeds) grow roots, stems, and leaves
Animals grow bigger and stronger
Growth is a defining feature of living things

topics.learning_outcome: Explain how plants and animals respond to their surroundings
key_concepts: Give examples of reactions to light, gravity, touch, or danger
Plants bend toward sunlight
Roots grow downward
Vines wrap around objects
Animals use senses to react (cheetah runs to chase prey)

topics.learning_outcome: Describe how plants and animals reproduce
key_concepts: Compare reproduction methods (seeds, cuttings, giving birth, laying eggs)
Plants reproduce by seeds (papaya, atis) or parts (camote, oregano)
Animals reproduce by giving birth (dog, goat) or laying eggs (chicken, turtle)

topics.topic_name: Characteristics of Living Things - Survival & Extinction
topics.learning_outcome: Explain why living things need to grow, respond, and reproduce | Recognize extinction if reproduction stops
key_concepts: Growth and response help living things survive
Reproduction ensures species continues
Without reproduction, species can become extinct
